Award.AwardTitle: Expansion and modernization of stable isotope analysis capabilities at the University of Texas Marine Science Institute
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Texas Marine Science Institute (UTMSI) http://www.utmsi.utexas.edu, established in 1941, has a long history of excellence with respect to innovation and application of stable isotope techniques in biogeochemical and ecological studies. This project will improve research infrastructure for stable isotope analyses at the UTMSI through acquisition of instrumentation as well as renovations to existing space that will house the instrumentation. A new isotope ratio mass spectrometer (IRMS) and peripheral components will be purchased to improve natural abundance stable isotope analysis capabilities. In addition, a unique Ammonium Isotope Retention Time Shift (AIRTS) high performance liquid chromatography system that is used for measurements of 15N-enriched ammonium in nitrogen process studies at the Institute will be upgraded. Improvement of stable isotope analysis capabilities at the UTMSI will advance scientific discovery by supporting more investigators, using a wider range of stable isotope techniques in their work. The new instrumentation will enable development and application of a variety of stable isotope techniques that are pushing the frontiers of biogeochemical and ecological studies, while enhancing our ability to support internal and external users that rely on existing analysis capabilities at the Institute.

With respect to education, the improvements will 1) promote greater training of graduate students and postdoctoral scientists in stable isotope analysis and application techniques, and 2) support additional opportunities for undergraduates to employ stable isotopes in research projects. A new undergraduate education program (Semester by the Sea) initiated in spring 2013 is bringing more undergraduates to the Institute. This program includes a major research component, and students in the program are encouraged to consider stable isotope applications as they develop research projects. The project also includes a commitment to public outreach. Project personnel will work with ongoing programs at the Institute to share their knowledge and interest in stable isotope applications with a broader audience. This will include development of a new food-web oriented module for the Summer Science Camp at UTMSI that highlights how stable isotopes help scientists understand dietary relationships.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project included 1) construction activities, 2) purchase of new equipment, and 3) upgrades of existing equipment to improve analytical services and capabilities at the University of Texas Marine Science Institute. A Delta V plus Isotope Ratio Mass Spectrometer with components for gas chromatography-based analyses of stable isotopes was purchased, and two existing Ammonium Isotope Retention Time Shift systems were upgraded with syringe pumps.  Space in UTMSI’s Estuarine Research Center was finished to house the new equipment as well as existing equipment for stable isotope analyses.  Construction activities were completed in October 2015, and instruments were fully installed and operational by March 2016. These improvements have enhanced UTMSI’s ability to support research and training at the Institute, and to provide analytical services to the broader research community.  The new lab space and equipment allows for greater productivity with respect to routine isotope analyses and encourages the development and application of novel methods.  In particular, the new equipment has significantly expanded UTMSI’s ability to support gas-phase and compound-specific stable isotope analyses.

The physical improvements described here were accompanied by a fundamental change in operation and training procedures related to stable isotope analyses at the Institute.  In the past, stable isotope analyses were primarily performed by one staff member.  UTMSI has now shifted to a multi-user approach that emphasizes hands-on training and allows for more efficient use of analytical capabilities.  The new laboratory is managed by a full-time employee with deep knowledge of instrument operation and maintenance. It is still possible to pay for samples to be run by the facility manager, but students and postdoctoral scientists are now strongly encouraged to learn how the instruments work and to run their own samples.  Three undergraduates and six graduate students were trained in the new lab between March 2016 (when the lab became operational) and the end of the grant period (July 2016).  The three undergraduates were participating in UTMSI’s NSF-funded Research Experiences for Undergraduates program.  Each had independent research projects that included stable isotope analyses, and they were able to learn the methods and run their own samples in the new lab.  The training/education opportunities created by this project are helping prepare students and postdoctoral scientist for careers in academic science as well as jobs in the government and private sectors.
